ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Fitting models, estimating parameters, data analysis, matlab
statistical analysis, Matlab skills, general organization and analysis of data
Learning everything about data analysis and Pet data analysis
Statistical, coding, and critical thinking regarding data.
This course helped me develop analytical approaches to data and problem solving skills when using programming for statistics.
Knowledge of statistical tests that should be useful when running experiments
I really like the part where Rich could relate the statistic analysis to PET imaging processing, which is really helpful for my research
A ton of math, statistics, and mathematical tools.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: important topics, professor very knowledgable
Weaknesses: not enough hands on work in the classroom. In class we go through lots of examples, but we don't actually do them, just watch. So I found it hard to apply what I learned in lecture to the assignments.
Very constructive, but moves at a harrowing pace. Overall, learned a lot and is already paying dividends helping me look at data in my research in a new way.

The course material is well organized and taught very clearly. The assignments were helpful in understanding how to apply the concepts from the lectures in MATLAB. However, the timing of final problem set made it difficult to have time to study for the final exam, and I did not feel like it was as helpful as other problem sets.

Richs lecture format and teaching style are not particularly conducive to my learning. I think some material could definitely be removed in order to focus more heavily on the parts directly applicable to our work.
The notes could be better organized to understand what question in the homework refer to which part of the notes.
Really well organized and structured to build upon previous lessons into more complex topics.

The recording of lectures and organized lecture notes (and accessible Matlab files) were really useful in facilitating self-learning if I missed a lecture or didn't understand something from lecture.
Slightly more organization in the help sessions or a problem set help notes/hints might be helpful

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, if they incorporate more doing rather than watching
Yes, I would because although it was a lot of hard work, it was very much worth it.
Unless it is required or you really like stats, I wouldnt take it.

Yes! It has gotten me to think of data analysis methods in ways other than just "how to apply this". There is a lot of "how this works", "why this works", "where this should work" that has made the class a 100000 times more interesting.
I would highly recommend this course. It was structured for practical applications, but I felt like it also taught why it worked.
Yes, it was very informative. It also was very difficult, I wish I could give it another go, I think I would learn just as much as I did this first time.
